title: Resort
text:
A resort (<a href="North%20American%20English">North American English</a>) is a self-contained commercial establishment that tries to provide most of a <a href="vacation">vacation</a>er's wants, such as food, drink, <a href="lodging">lodging</a>, <a href="sport">sport</a>s, <a href="entertainment">entertainment</a>, and <a href="shopping">shopping</a>, on the premises. The term "resort" may be used for a <a href="hotel">hotel</a> property that provides an array of amenities, typically including entertainment and recreational activities. A hotel is frequently a central feature of a resort, such as the <a href="Grand%20Hotel%20%28Mackinac%20Island%29">Grand Hotel</a> at <a href="Mackinac%20Island%2C%20Michigan">Mackinac Island, Michigan</a>. Some resorts are also condominium complexes that are timeshares or owned fractionally or wholly owned <a href="condominium">condominium</a>. A resort is not always a commercial establishment operated by a single company, but in the late 20th century, that sort of facility became more common.
In <a href="British%20English">British English</a>, "resort" means a town which people visit for holidays and days out which usually contains hotels at which such holidaymakers stay. Examples would include <a href="Blackpool">Blackpool</a> and <a href="Brighton">Brighton</a>.
Destination resort.
A <a href="destination%20hotel">destination resort</a> is a resort that itself contains the necessary guest attraction capabilities so it does not need to be near a destination (town, historic site, theme park, or other) to attract its patrons. A commercial establishment at a resort destination such as a recreational area, a scenic or historic site, <a href="amusement%20park">amusement park</a>, a gaming facility, or other tourist attraction may compete with other businesses at a destination. Consequently, another quality of a destination resort is that it offers food, drink, lodging, sports, entertainment, and shopping within the facility so that guests have no need to leave the facility throughout their stay. Commonly, the facilities are of higher quality than would be expected if one were to stay at a hotel or eat in a town's restaurants. Some examples are Atlantis in the <a href="Bahamas">Bahamas</a>; the <a href="Walt%20Disney%20World%20Resort">Walt Disney World Resort</a>, near <a href="Orlando%2C%20Florida">Orlando, Florida</a>, <a href="United%20States">United States</a>; <a href="PortAventura%20World">PortAventura World</a>, near <a href="Barcelona">Barcelona</a> on the <a href="Costa%20Daurada">Costa Daurada</a> in <a href="Spain">Spain</a>; Costa do Sauípe, <a href="Northeastern%20Brazil">Northeastern Brazil</a>; Laguna Phuket, <a href="Thailand">Thailand</a> and Sun City, near <a href="Johannesburg">Johannesburg</a>, <a href="South%20Africa">South Africa</a>. Closely related to resorts are convention and large meeting sites. Generally, they occur in cities, where special meeting halls, together with ample accommodations and varied dining and entertainment, are provided.
All-inclusive resort.
An <a href="all-inclusive">all-inclusive</a> resort charges a fixed price that includes most or all items. At a minimum, most inclusive resorts include lodging, unlimited food, drink, sports activities, and entertainment for the fixed price. In recent years, the number of resorts in the United States offering "all-inclusive" amenities has decreased dramatically. In 1961, over half offered such plans, but in 2007, less than a tenth do so.
All-inclusive resorts are found in the <a href="Caribbean">Caribbean</a>, particularly in <a href="Jamaica">Jamaica</a>, <a href="Dominican%20Republic">Dominican Republic</a>; in <a href="Egypt">Egypt</a>, and elsewhere. Notable examples are <a href="Club%20Med">Club Med</a>, <a href="Sandals%20Resorts">Sandals Resorts</a>, and <a href="Beaches%20Resorts">Beaches Resorts</a>.
An all-inclusive resort includes three meals daily, <a href="soft%20drink">soft drink</a>s, most <a href="alcoholic%20drink">alcoholic drink</a>s, <a href="gratuities">gratuities</a>, and usually other services in the price. Many also offer sports and other activities included in the price as well. They are often located in warmer regions. The all-inclusive model originated in the <a href="Club%20Med">Club Med</a> resorts, which were founded by the Belgian <a href="G%C3%A9rard%20Blitz%20%28entrepreneur%29">Gérard Blitz</a>.
Some all-inclusive resorts are designed for specific groups. For example, some resorts cater for adults only, and even more-specialized properties accept couples only. Other all-inclusive resorts are geared toward families, with facilities like craft centers, game rooms, and water parks to keep children of all ages entertained. All-inclusive resorts are also very popular locations for destination weddings.
Recreation.
A <a href="destination%20spa">spa resort</a> is a short-term residential/lodging facility with the primary purpose of providing individual services for spa goers to develop healthy habits. Historically, many such spas were developed at the location of natural hot springs or sources of mineral waters. Typically over a seven-day stay, such facilities provide a comprehensive program that includes spa services, physical fitness activities, healthy diet programs, and special interest programming.
Golf resorts are resorts that cater specifically to the sport of <a href="golf">golf</a>, and they include access to one or more golf courses and/or clubhouses. Golf resorts typically provide golf packages that provide visitors with all greens and cart fees, range balls, accommodations, and meals.
In <a href="North%20America">North America</a>, a ski resort is generally a destination resort in a ski area. The term is less likely to refer to a town or village.
A megaresort is a type of destination resort of an exceptionally-large size, such as those along the <a href="Las%20Vegas%20Strip">Las Vegas Strip</a>. In <a href="Singapore">Singapore</a>, "<a href="integrated%20resort">integrated resort</a>" is a <a href="euphemism">euphemism</a> for a <a href="casino">casino</a>-based destination resort.
A <a href="holiday%20village">holiday village</a> is a type of self-contained resort in <a href="Europe">Europe</a> whose accommodation is generally in <a href="villa">villa</a>s. A <a href="holiday%20camp">holiday camp</a>, in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>, refers to a resort whose accommodation is in <a href="chalet">chalet</a>s or <a href="static%20caravan">static caravan</a>s.
Timeshare.
There are more than 1500 <a href="timeshare">timeshare</a> resorts in the United States that are operated by major hospitality, timeshare-specific, or independent companies. They represent 198,000 residences and nearly 9 million owners, who pay an average $880 per year in maintenance fees. A reported 16% of the residences became <a href="vacation%20rentals">vacation rentals</a>.
Resort towns.
Towns that are resorts or in which <a href="tourism">tourism</a> or vacationing is a major part of the local activity are sometimes called <a href="resort%20towns">resort towns</a>. If by the sea, they are called <a href="seaside%20resort">seaside resort</a>s. Inland resorts include <a href="ski%20resort">ski resort</a>s, <a href="mountain%20resort">mountain resort</a>s and <a href="spa%20town">spa town</a>s. Well-known resort towns include <a href="Punta%20Cana">Punta Cana</a> in <a href="Dominican%20Republic">Dominican Republic</a>, <a href="Bandipur">Bandipur</a> in <a href="Nepal">Nepal</a>, <a href="Bali">Bali</a> in Indonesia, <a href="Sochi">Sochi</a> in <a href="Russia">Russia</a>, Mount Lebanon Tourism in <a href="Lebanon">Lebanon</a>, <a href="Barizo">Barizo</a> in <a href="Spain">Spain</a>, <a href="Cortina%20d%27Ampezzo">Cortina d'Ampezzo</a> in Italy, <a href="Druskininkai">Druskininkai</a> in <a href="Lithuania">Lithuania</a>, <a href="Cartagena%20de%20Indias">Cartagena de Indias</a> in <a href="Colombia">Colombia</a>, <a href="Canc%C3%BAn">Cancún</a> in Mexico, <a href="Newport%2C%20Rhode%20Island">Newport, Rhode Island</a>, and <a href="Key%20West%2C%20Florida">Key West, Florida</a>, in the United States, <a href="Ischgl">Ischgl</a> in <a href="Austria">Austria</a>, <a href="St.%20Moritz">St. Moritz</a> in <a href="Switzerland">Switzerland</a> and <a href="Blackpool">Blackpool</a> in the <a href="United%20Kingdom">United Kingdom</a>.
A <a href="resort%20island">resort island</a> is an island or an archipelago that contains resorts, hotels, restaurants, tourist attractions, and its amenities. <a href="Maldives">Maldives</a> is considered to have the best island resorts, which have become famous among the top celebrities and sportspersons around the world.
<a href="Seaside%20resort">Seaside resort</a>s are located on a coast. In the United Kingdom, many seaside towns have turned to other entertainment industries, and some of them have much nightlife. The cinemas and theatres often remain to become host to a number of pubs, bars, restaurants, and nightclubs. Most of their entertainment facilities cater to local people, and the beaches still remain popular during the summer months.
In Europe and North America, <a href="ski%20resort">ski resort</a>s are towns and villages in ski areas, with support services for skiing such as hotels and <a href="chalet">chalet</a>s, equipment rental, <a href="ski%20school">ski school</a>s and <a href="ski%20lift">ski lift</a>s to access the slopes.
Resorts for different purposes also exist. An example is <a href="Yulara">Yulara</a>, <a href="Northern%20Territory">Northern Territory</a>, which exists to serve <a href="Uluru">Uluru (Ayers Rock)</a> and <a href="Kata%20Tjuta">Kata Tjuta (The Olgas)</a> in <a href="Australia">Australia</a>.
